comments.commentBody: Maybe the Yanks already have the front line starters they need. Garcia and Colon have been excellent in the past and are looking pretty good. They are canny experienced pros. May prove to be great off season pickups (they are both doing better than Lee so far…).

Well I definitely agree with Patricia that I did not find this puzzle particularly easy.  In fact, I thought it was a very nice challenge for a Saturday afternoon.  Alas, sleeping in until 5 meant that Amy had already switched over the standings to Sunday and I couldn't see where my 18:48 time fit in this time around, but I've been in the top 10 pretty consistently on her site.
A cohesive and beautiful series. Transitional "tipping points" are definitely conveyed and felt.

For the people who might not have gotten it (and MOL, I think it's ok now):

Bookmark the twitter page. To come to the blog, go to the twitter page and click on the link at the top of that page for the day's blog post.
http://twitter.com/nytimeswordplay

You don't have to twitter, tweet or chirp. It's a legal alternate pathway here that is not metered. And yes, we have Deb to thank even though her inherent modesty prevents her from taking a bow. Must be some Canadian blood.
Anonymous?  I don't know if Firesign Theatre originated the line, but from "Nick Danger, Third Eye":  "Suddenly, he stopped on a dime!  Unfortunately, the dime was in Mr. Rococo's pocket."

I did have fun finding the quotations, and harassing all my friends with my newly found catalog of paraprosdokians (which is what all these one-liners happen to be).  My favorites, though, were two 19's that didn't make it, both courtesy of Rodney Dangerfield: When I was a kid my parents moved a lot BUT I ALWAYS FOUND THEM, and My wife made me join a bridge club.  I JUMP OFF NEXT THURSDAY.  I also liked another 20 from Emo Philips: People always ask me, "Where were you when Kennedy was shot?" WELL I DON'T HAVE AN ALIBI.  But I liked the Indian giver one better.  Part of the problem was that Will and I decided fairly early that every theme entry had to be from a different comedian (and hopefully not *too* well known), and coupling that with the symmetry requirements restricted the possibilities quite a bit.
Rats! Tree stump out of closet again! Please read Martin @20! Deb has tried and tried to keep us "all in the family."

Patricia @31 - thanks to you I found Patrick's "priceless" cartoon - I shall now try Uncle Martin's post.  You are not a dummy - no way, cuz I'd have to be one too.  Did not find all this easy today!!  Now on to Sunday's... Vamonos a ver....

Angelsong et al – All I know is that with my $39 annual premium crossword subscription I have unlimited access to the puzzle and blog for the year and was told by the NYT customer service that the 20 access restriction applied only to access to articles for online readers who do not pay anything.  The only time I am prompted is when my subscription expires.  Maybe the paper is prompting you about your renewal date.  There are ways to contact the NYT customer service so you might want to do that.

One reason some solvers will find this nut a tad harder to crack is that Matt really tries to provide unique clues to common answers. As a result, there are few gimmes. Even __ Minor is tricky, STREAM, AOL and URL are freshly clued, and SIT (UP) is fresh.

Apart from the minor nit of the repeated "THROUGH" in the clue and the answer, this was a perfect smile-inducer for the weekend!

In the April  16 puzzle the answer for 6 down (Lance Cpl.'s grp")is given as USM. NOBODY, particularly  those of us who serve or served  in the Marine Corps, calls this branch of the service USM. One could argue that USM isn't incorrect. On the other hand, it isn't in general, knowledgeable use.

That "anonymous" quote at 36A is similar to one I've heard from Fire Sign Theater. It goes, "He stopped on a dime. Unfortunately the dime was in Mr. Rococo's pocket." I don't know who stole it from whom. I used to be able to quote a lot of Fire Sign Theater dialog. They were the precursors to Cheech & Chong.

Re LUCIA di Lammermoor. The Met Opera just put on that opera this past month with Natalie Dessay playing the title role. No one does it better than Natalie.

ha! I loved your Boy Story Deb - my son David, at about the same age, decided to put a "Call Police!!" sign in his bedroom window....I was gobsmacked when the police knocked at the door ready for action!

Completely loved the theme entries! But then I love slapstick comedy too har har. Real rib-ticklers these! Glad I did not SKIP IT (as if i ever would...). Great misdirections!

A potential misquote and possible error in the puzzle:

"I have the heart of a young boy, it is in a glass jar on my desk" is actually a quote from Robert Bloch, the author of the book Psycho, the basis for the Hitchcock film, as well as many other works of horror. I believe that Stephen King has quoted Robert Bloch at times, but I am pretty sure that Robert Bloch did say it first.

Paul Hawken added this thought on failure as a component of a flexible, durable, resilient system:

This reminds me of what someone said about Y2K (Stewart Brand mentioned this to me), that the system didn't break down at the millennium because the system breaks down constantly. The constancy of failure is resiliency. Long live failure. Lester Brown's predictions about collapse have not been prescient because it is not a food system; there are food systems.

basic would be to understand and implement the (fractal) field effect symmetry which made the planets biofield self regulating in the first place...
www.goldenmean.info/selforganization
once you understand the definition of pain (where fractality is broken -charge bleeds)
then you can address the pain of earth

As the advanced cultures have moved into a world of scientific and technological progress, they have imagined that our achievement of some mastery and control over nature and the material world requires that the human being be punished.

It’s as if, after this first assertion of real power, the human being has become shy and self-doubting. After a long history of fear and helplessness, we experience the thrill of power – and no rebuke to this power. Like a lover suddenly shy after quick, total and unexpected conquest, the human being stands startled and confused. Nature gives herself to man.

There must be a terrible price for such mastery and pleasure – right? Our comforts, our luxuries, our ease – what have we done to deserve this? This monstrous felicity.

And so the rhetoric of advanced human cultures circles mercilessly around this sense of startled guilt, and a long series of deeply religious gestures begins. We are guilty. We have gone too far. We will atone.

Those among us who imagine themselves the least religious are of course the most religious: calling for endless and great sacrifices. All must be equal. Justice must prevail over the illicit exercise of power. Power, control and mastery are terrible in themselves; the human being must turn away from its rapacity and hunger. Or it will be punished.

The only thing lacking in our brains is a temporary inability to see through this nonsense. The human being will continue on its awesome and splendid course. There will be no punishment of any kind. Those who doubt this and lose faith in the human being will fall away from life. But there is no turning back; every genie is out of every bottle and the best human beings will always drain the bottle, unashamed, to the lees.

It is a great logical fallacy to attribute human motives to nature or to natural forces.

This fallacy has a long and distinguished history, dating as it does back at least to the ancient Greeks with their whimsical gods of sky and sea, Zeus and Poseidon, Hera and Athena and all the other Olympians.

But it is still a fallacy. At best it is an evocative literary device. At worst it is seriously muddled thinking.

Anyone who has ever endured a desert sandstorm, a flash flood, a tornado, a hurricane or a gale at sea in a small boat should know that nature is not vengeful, malicious, whimsical or capricious or indeed driven by any human motive whatsoever.

Nature is indifferent.

Supremely indifferent and utterly uncaring.

The wind blows because it can, not to reward or punish any human under heaven. The waters rise because the wind blows them, not because of the sin or virtue of any man in their path.

But there is a human habit to look for patterns even where there are none. And there is also a human habit to project our thoughts and emotions onto inanimate objects which are incapable of either thought or emotion.

Because there is a very human yearning for nature and nature's forces to have thoughts and emotions. Many, many people would much rather believe that the world is the goddess Gaia and not a random collection of chemicals and rocks.

If there is a goddess Gaia, then us feeble humans might be able to propitiate her wrath and win her favor with appropriate ritual and sacrifice.

Paper recycling, for example. And cap-and-trade, or at least a hefty carbon tax.

In the absence of an earth goddess whose favor might be won, with ritual and sacrifice, people would have to admit that when faced with nature's might, we are as helpless as an oak leaf in a hurricane.

And to many, many people, that mental admission of helplessness is unbearable.

Have you picked a couple of irrational guys to boost. Here is Michel T. Klare speaking both for himself and Bill McKibben:
"As the planet warms and glaciers melt, sea levels will rise, inundating coastal areas, destroying cities, and flooding low-lying croplands. Drought will become endemic in many once-productive farming areas, reducing food supplies for hundreds of millions of people. Many plant and animal species that are key to human livelihoods, including various species of trees, food crops, and fish, will prove incapable of adjusting to these climate changes and so cease to exist.“
“Bill McKibben is right: we no longer live on the ’cozy, taken-for-granted’ planet formerly known as Earth. We inhabit a new place, already changed dramatically by the intervention of humankind. But we are not acting upon a passive, impotent entity unable to defend itself against human transgression. Sad to say, we will learn to our dismay of the immense powers available to Eaarth, the Avenger.“
First, his description of the the supposed consequences of global warming is completely wrong. There is no global warming now, either anthropogenic or not, because global temperatures are not going up. This you can find out simply by looking at satellite global temperature records, available to everyone on the Web for the last 31 years. During this entire period there was only one short warming incident that raised global temperature by a third of a degree in four years and then stopped (Read "What Warming?" pages 31-36). But McKibben is worse with his vision of a planet destroyed by that same global warming. I simply cannot understand the lack of both scientific expertise and intelligence that can put such drivel out and claim that iot is backed up by a "consensus" of 2500 climate "scientists." These people have not the slightest idea how to evaluate scientific observations of nature and how to check out hypotheses against observed facts. Observed fact: Satellite measurements of lower tropospheric air temperature do not show any warming trend before 1998. This same period appears as a "late twentieth century warming" in NASA, NOAA, and Met Office temperature curves. Observed fact: satellite temperatures during this period oscillate around a fixed mean for twenty years. Observed fact: the oscillations trace out five El Nino peaks during this period. Observed fact: the valleys between the peaks correlate with La Nina periods. Observed fact: when you compare the satellite curve with either NASA or Met Office curve these same oscillations are present. The first four of the Met Office curve even have the same height as the peaks in the satellite curve. Observed fact: the valleys between the peaks have all been made shallow, and thanks to this device both curves have an upward slope that is claimed to mean warming. Question: is it possible that these curves are wrong because they have reduced the valley depth by a factor ofvtwo or are the satellites wrong by making the valleys twice as deep as they should be. I have not mentioned NOAA's temperature curve yet but it turns out that they have gotten rid of the valleys entirely and their curve just follows the peaks in the beginning. Why even keep the valleys if they don't contribute to warming seems to be their motto. This puts their curve in the category of not just reducing but eliminating the La Nina valleys that exist in the temperature record. And this variety of ways of achieving a rising temperature curve tells us that these rising curves are all human-made or anthropogenic fakes. And when it comes to the twenty-first century temperature, satellites show a warm platform from 2002 to 2008 but no warming. And this in turn gives way to the 2008 La Nina cooling which re-initiates the ENSO oscillations interrupted by the super El Nino. This also means no warming in our future except for the periodic El Nino peaks that ENSO will send our way. But the esteemed keepers of global temperature do not see it this way - their curves already have an imaginary warming in 2011. NASA carries this charade so far as to claim that 2005 was warmer than the 1998 super El Nino which is absurd. And they all tell us that dangerous global warming is still ahead, guaranteed because ever-increasing carbon dioxide and its greenhouse effect. But there is a problem with this fantasy: The infrared absorption band of the atmosphere is already saturated and no further addition of CO2 can increase the already-existing greenhouse warming. I am not making this up but am relying on actual measurements made by weather balloons. Ferenc Miskolczy used the NOAA database of weather balloon observations that goes back to 1948 and determined that the transparency of the atmosphere in the infrared band where carbon dioxide absorbs had not changed for the last 61 years. This means that the greenhouse absorption signature of this added carbon dioxide simply isn't there. And no absorption, no greenhouse effect, case closed.

Bryant's annual salary is $25 million. The $100 thousand fine was basically a slap on the hand. He used a term which is not only pejorative, but aggressive, as well. If the NBA and Commissioner Stern had really been intent on sending a message that this use of offensive language was unacceptable, Bryant would have been suspended for at least one game. The proportionately small fine was simply a public relations move.

Bill Russell was the greatest defensive and team player in the history of the game; Michael Jordan the greatest outside player; Wilt the greatest scorer; Oscar and Jerry West were the greatest outside players of their time; and Larry Bird the best combination of inside and outside player.  Bill Walton was the greatest combination of Russell and Wilt and Jabbar we've seen; that his injuries derailed him is the intrusion of life into professional basketball.

Walton played a beautiful game--tremendous passer, so much basketball intelligence. At his healthiest, he was a better all-around center than Abdul-Jabbar, but he's right that the body of Kareem's work should put him in the top spot.

The game where Walton went 21-22 is still the single best individual collegiate performance I've ever seen. Despite missing more games in his pro career than he played, he earned his spot in the HOF by being a winner. His insights are keen. Thanks for talking to him.

I don't think I can put it any better than Maddie1 did. They're done, they're horrendous, there is a losing culture, a stench that will not go away until every last player with any part in it is purged and probably the team is sold to new owners.

Trade Reyes, trade Beltran, trade Pelfrey, Wright, Davis, Pagan, Santana, Bay...all of them. Make Daniel Murphy a bat boy after that out he made at 3rd tonight.

Then fire the hopelessly stupid Wilpons and bring someone with a brain in here to restore some dignity.

A disgraceful, uncompetitive display that is way too familiar.

I started wearing fragrance in college after a Nordstroms sales woman let me take my time and really helped me see my options.  It was a super low pressure situation and she was really helpful.  I actually slept on it ($50 was a lot of money!).  Alas, I've since moved and can't stop at Nordstroms anymore :(  But Sephora and their samples and absence of harassing clerks is a nice second choice.
